F_2007_530.pdf:
Decree laying down provisions applicable to equipment, sold new or second-hand, for the application of phytosanitary
products 

6. Products Concerned
Sprayers (new and second-hand) 

7. Notification Under Another Act
None. 

8. Main Content
Article 41 of Act 2006-1772 of 30 December 2006 on water and aquatic environments (French abbreviation LEMA)
introduces an obligation for sprayers, sold new or second-hand by machinery professionals for use in French territory,
to comply with provisions designed to reduce risks to the environment and public health. 
The principles of the ‘new approach’ Community doctrine were used in drafting texts implementing this article: the draft
Decree to which this notification relates provides for an order defining the requirements and creates a regulatory
framework for it. It also provides for the publication, for information purposes, of references to standards, technical
specifications or manufacturing procedures underpinning the presumption of compliance with these requirements. The
said order and notice are notified at the same time as the draft Decree. 
These requirements do not cover operator safety, insofar as such requirements are already laid down in the
Employment Code, transposing Directive 98/37/EC relating to machinery. 
Article 1 of the draft Decree introduces various articles in the Rural Code. These articles cover the definition of various
terms used to set rules relating to sprayers, followed by requirements applicable to sprayers sold new, requirements
applicable to second-hand sprayers, and miscellaneous provisions (penalties and orders to be issued in implementation
of the Decree): 

Definitions 
Article D. 526-1 defines the term ‘sprayer’ based on the concept of machinery taken from the Machinery Directive
(concept defined in Article R. 233-83 and R. 233-83-1 of the Employment Code, transposing Article 1 of Directive
98/37/EC relating to machinery). It distinguishes between ‘new sprayers’, for which the applicable requirements may be
taken into account at the design stage, and ‘second-hand sprayers’, for which the applicable requirements must be
defined in consideration of the possibilities for repairs. This distinction is similar to that made for machinery in Article R.
233-49-3 of the Employment Code. 
It also defines the term ‘machinery professional’, the person responsible for compliance when selling a sprayer, which is
designed to encompass manufacturers and importers of sprayers as well as retailers of agricultural machinery.
Professional users of sprayers such as farmers, cooperatives for the use of agricultural equipment or service providers
for the application of phytosanitary products are not affected, insofar as they do not have competence to ensure the

6. Products Concerned
Use of processing aids in certain foodstuffs 

7. Notification Under Another Act
- 

8. Main Content
The draft amends the Order of 19 October 2006 on the use of processing aids in the manufacture of certain foodstuffs and drinks for human consumption 

(http://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/affichTexte.do?idTexte=JORFTEXT000000271061&fastPos=4&fastReqId=1842360167&categorieLien=cid&oldAction=rechTexte). 

9. Brief Statement of Grounds
This draft order authorises eleven new enzymes by mutual recognition and extends the authorisations of four enzymes that are already authorised. It authorises a new

5. Title
Order on the contents of the user manual provided with the packaging of unmanned aerial vehicles and their spare parts 

Page 2 of 6

EUROPEAN COMMISSION
GROWTH DIRECTORATE-GENERAL 
 
Single Market for goods
Prevention of Technical Barriers

 



6. Products Concerned
Civilian unmanned aerial vehicles (drones) 

7. Notification Under Another Act
- 

8. Main Content
Due to the increase in the number of unlawful flights over sensitive French sites by drones since autumn 2014, two members of the
French Parliament tabled a draft law in spring 2016 on improving safety measures when using civilian drones. This draft was the
result of the Government report to Parliament entitled ‘The rise in civilian aerial drones in France: challenges and possible responses
from the State’, published in October 2015. 
The law was finally adopted by the French Parliament and enacted on 24 October 2016 (Law No 2016-1428). It imposes new
obligations on pilots, owners or manufacturers of civilian unmanned aerial vehicles. These are intended to prevent incidents posing a
risk to State security, and make pilots accountable. 
The Draft Order notified by France to the Member States and European Commission under Directive (EU) 2015/1535 aims to define
the contents of the user manual to be provided with unmanned aerial vehicles and their main spare parts, pursuant to Article L425-1
of the Consumer Code. The manual shall include the same amount of information as the manual placed online by the French
Directorate-General for Civil Aviation for recreational drones (see
https://www.ecologique-solidaire.gouv.fr/sites/default/files/R%C3%A8gles%20d%27usage%20d%27un%20drone%20de%20loisir.pdf);
using the manual published by the Directorate-General for Civil Aviation (DGAC) is an acceptable means of compliance with the
requirement. 

9. Brief Statement of Grounds
This Draft Order therefore aims to supplement, for reasons of guaranteeing public safety and State security, the French regulatory
framework relating to unmanned aerial vehicles established by the Order of 17 December 2015 relating to the design of civilian
unmanned aerial vehicles, the conditions for their use and the skills required of those using them and the Order of 17 December
2015 as amended on 30 March 2017 on the use of airspace by unmanned aerial vehicles. 
The requirements contained in this Draft Order aim to define the contents of the user manual which shall accompany unmanned
aerial vehicles and their main spare parts. 
The aim is to ensure that purchasers of drones (new or second-hand) receive a minimum amount of information on the regulations
concerning drones so that they act in a safe and respectful manner. The recommendations in the aforementioned report which have
been included in the law are based on, in particular, the belief that greater compliance with the regulations by well-meaning users will
greatly decrease the number of false alarms and also facilitate the work of the services responsible for the prevention of attacks to
the security and protection of sensitive sites.

6. Products Concerned
Automatic weighing equipment: discontinuous adding machines

7. Notification Under Another Act
-

8. Main Content
The aim of this text is to lay down rules for the inspection
of discontinuous totalizing weighing equipment: metrological
requirements, operating conditions, technical requirements,
installation requirements and metrological inspection.

It should be noted that Articles6, 8 and 16 of Decree
No88-682 of 6May1988 on the inspection of measuring
instruments refer to equipment lawfully manufactured and
marketed in the MemberStates of the Community.

9. Brief Statement of Grounds
The current regulations for these instruments date back to
1965. These regulations need to be updated and to be brought
within the scope of Decree No88-082 of 6May1988.

10. Reference Documents - Basic Texts
Decree No 88-088 of 6 May 1988

No

F_2008_333.pdf:
Order laying down the technical requirements applicable to individual sewerage systems receiving a gross load of organic waste less than or equal to 1.2 kg/day of BOD5 

6. Products Concerned
Product codes concerned: B10, B30. 

7. Notification Under Another Act
- 

8. Main Content
The Water Act of 30 December 2006 significantly amended the existing regulatory framework. 
Furthermore, Article R. 2224-17 of the French Local Authorities Code lays down that the technical specifications applicable to individual sewerage systems receiving a gross load of organic waste less than or equal
to 1.2 kg of BOD5 shall be laid down by joint order of the Ministers responsible for Health, Housing and the Environment. 
Moreover, Article L. 1331-1-1 of the Public Health Code lays down that the maintenance methods for individual sewerage systems shall be defined by order of the Ministers responsible for Health, the Environment
and Housing. 

The notified draft text follows on from these provisions and is intended to revise the Order of 6 May 1996 laying down the technical specifications applicable to individual sewerage systems. 

During the drafting of this text, the principles of the “new approach” Community doctrine were applied: the notified draft Order provides for compliance with the essential requirements of the construction products
directive and the technical specifications of the reference documents which are the standards. It allows the publication of these reference documents, the list of bodies appointed to perform the technical
assessment, the technical assessment protocol, the procedure for requesting an assessment, the list of approved systems and the corresponding technical data sheets. 
This draft text is divided into 5 sections which define the general principles; the minimum technical specifications applicable to treatment; the minimum technical specifications applicable to drainage; maintenance
and disposal of individual sewerage by-products and sewage and the specific cases of dry toilets. The annex to the text lays down the list of systems approved by the co-signatory ministers. 

This draft does not affect existing technical specifications and reaffirms the purifying capacity of soil and other validated materials. However, it amends the authorisation procedure for innovative processes, which
were previously validated by the French Higher Public Health Council. 
The draft text provides for the drafting of a protocol which, in particular, makes it possible to show that the conditions of installation of these treatment systems, as specified by the manufacturer, make it possible to
guarantee that the systems into which they are integrated comply with: 
- the minimum requirements described in the draft Order, 
- as well as the following maximum concentrations after treatment: 30 mg/l in suspended solids (SS) and 35 mg/l for BOD5.
